data.title: API: (built-in Markdown extension) interface `TocEntry` should have `level` as an attribute
data.body:
Currently, we have this interface [vscode/extensions/markdown/src/tableOfContentsProvider.ts L12](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/7e539de2f4a8872909a748cfe59f0dd1ea1ce0fc/extensions/markdown/src/tableOfContentsProvider.ts#L12)

```typescript
export interface TocEntry {
	slug: string;
	text: string;
	line: number;
	location: vscode.Location;
}
```

If we call `tocProvider.getToc()` on this example document

```markdown
Setext Heading 1
===

Setext Heading 2
---

<http://spec.commonmark.org/0.28/#setext-heading>

# ATX Heading
```

We get this result

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7588612/29499664-3f178868-8649-11e7-9101-60d37a9aa576.png)

The information about (setext) heading level is missing.

data.title: Test: Electron Update 1.7.3
data.body:
Refs: #28582

**OS**
- [x] Windows @rebornix 
- [x] OS X @jrieken 
- [x] Linux @aeschli 

Complexity: 4

We have updated Electron to version `1.7.3` and thereby jumped 2 Chrome releases (from `56` to `58`) and 5 minor node.js release (from `7.4.0` to `7.9.0`) and many other dependency updates. This test item asks for exploratory testing focusing on native integration where possible:

- Drag and drop
- Menus and context menus
- Window management and multiple windows
- UI regressions
- Accessibility regressions

data.title: Bump electron version to 1.7.5
data.body: Fixes #28582

data.title: css.colorDecorators breaks word wrapping
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.15.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 x64

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Settings:
```
    "editor.wordWrap": "on",
    "css.colorDecorators.enable": true
```
2. Code example:
```
   .form-control:focus { border-color: #141d36; box-shadow: 0 1px 1px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.075) inset, 0 0 4px rgba(165,128,57,0.6); -webkit-box-shadow: 0 1px 1px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.075) inset, 0 0 4px rgba(165,128,57,0.6); }
```

With colorDecorators disabled word wrapping works fine. After enabling it wordWrap completely ignores the width of added decorators and wrapes the code as they are not there what makes parts of the code to be pushed out of viewport.

I think it would be better to just underline the colors accordingly instead adding new elements next to it.
Also it would be great to add some margin between wrapped code and minimap (or whatever is on the right).

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Copy line keyboard shortcut for Ubuntu
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.15.1
- OS Version: Ubuntu 17.04

In Ubuntu `add cursor above/below` can be done with both <kbd>Ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>Shift</kbd>+<kbd>Up/Down</kbd> and with <kbd>Alt</kbd>+<kbd>Shift</kbd>+<kbd>Up/Down</kbd>. 
Instead of using <kbd>Ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>Alt</kbd>+<kbd>Shift</kbd> to `copy line up/down`, <kbd>Alt</kbd>+<kbd>Shift</kbd>+<kbd>Up/Down</kbd> should be assigned for it as <kbd>Ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>Alt</kbd>+<kbd>Shift</kbd> and <kbd>Ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>Alt</kbd> are already mapped in Ubuntu's Unity and in GNOME, and <kbd>Shift</kbd>+<kbd>Alt</kbd> is already being used for copying line up/down in Windows.

data.title: Text gets selected, to the next line, when the menu bar auto hides
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.15.1 (41abd21afdf7424c89319ee7cb0445cc6f376959, 2017-08-16T18:07:25.676Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
spellright|ban|1.1.16
python|don|0.7.0
cpptools|ms-|0.12.3
csharp|ms-|1.12.1
PowerShell|ms-|1.4.1
blank-line-organizer|rin|0.1.2
sort-lines|Tyr|1.3.0
change-case|wma|1.0.0



---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Set your menu bar to auto hide (i.e. set it to toggle).
2. Press Alt to show the menu bar.
3. Click somewhere near the beginning of a line of text in your currently visible text document.
4. As the menu bar disappears, notice that the text gets selected, started from the position where you clicked and ending on the line below where you clicked.

Expected:
Nothing should get selected when the menu bar auto hides. The cursor should simply be wherever you clicked.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes/No

data.title: Interactive Playground still tells you to use Emmet with Tab (old defunct functionality?)
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.15.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 Pro 1703

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open Code
2. Click Interactive Playground
3. Scroll down to:

> Emmet
Emmet takes the snippets idea to a whole new level: you can type CSS-like expressions that can be dynamically parsed, and produce output depending on what you type in the abbreviation. To use Emmet simply press tab after a valid piece for Emmet syntax and the expansion will occur. Try it by pressing tab after ul>li.item$*5 to see Emmet in action.
`ul>li.item$*5 `

Just installed Code and was wondering why this didn't do anything. Googled and found this recent issue (https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/32243) saying the Tab functionality had been removed. So the tutorial probably needs reworking

data.title: Escaped ("\") characters in strings and regex should be highlighted
data.body:
In Sublime text, when syntax was set to JavaScript, escaped characters in strings would be highlighted since they are special characters, not literal characters. The highlighting of these special escaped characters made the strings easier to read.

In this example, the `\n` should be highlighted.
````
/new\nline/
````

In this example the `\"` should be highlighted

```
{ "key": "value with a \"quote\" inside it" }
```

This should apply across the board to any languages that feature this method of escaping characters in strings.

}
4. Run Code

    Error occurred during initialization of VM
    Unable to load native library: The specified procedure could not be found


I'm new to this so kindly help. My environment variable named JAVA_HOME has C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.8.0_121

data.title: no new line when pressing CTRL+C in terminal
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.14.2
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1.  open integrated terminal
2.  run long running operation
3.  press ctrl + c
4.  `Terminate batch job (Y/N)?` Shows up
5.  press ctrl + c again

Expected to jump to a new cleared line, but actually just a ^C shows up:

`Terminate batch job (Y/N)? ^C`

Another variation of this issue is to just:
1.  open integrated terminal
2.  either enter some text or not.
3.  press ctrl + c

In a normal cmd this would jump to a new cleared line, but actually nothing happens

This happens only in windows and not in mac.
This happens both with cmd & powershell.

data.title: Debug API: Add the ability to open source files using their source reference
data.body:
I'd like to implement a "Loaded Scripts Explorer" for the Firefox debug adapter but realized that I can only open the files shown in that explorer if they are "local", but not if they'd need to be fetched from Firefox via the debug adapter (e.g. third-party libraries loaded from a CDN, scripts injected by a Browser extension, etc.). However, the ability to view such "remote" files is one of the primary use cases for this explorer (IMHO).

It is already possible to view a "remote" file if it is referenced by a stackframe - in this case it is fetched via the debug adapter using its numeric source reference. But I can't do that in my explorer for two reasons:
* I can't tell VS Code about source files and their associated source references (unless they show up in a stackframe)
* I can't ask VS Code to open a file using its source reference

I was thinking about implementing a document provider to work around these limitations but that would only be a partial solution: VS Code wouldn't know about the relationship between the files from that content provider and the debugger, so it wouldn't be possible to set breakpoints and if the user stepped into that file later on, VS Code would open a second tab for the file (because it is fetched from the debug content provider and hence is a different file from VS Code's point of view).

My proposal would be:
1. add a `NewSourceEvent` (containing a `Source` object in its body) to the debug protocol
2. add the ability to open a file using a `debugSessionId` and a `sourceReference`

data.title: Markdown `slugify` misses backticks
data.body:
This pattern:

https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/40bd5d9859f9f2e33554cb5c3895978c50c6ae94/extensions/markdown/src/tableOfContentsProvider.ts#L75

should contain a backtick. It currently doesn't which for example breaks Ctrl+click navigation:

```md
Link to heading: [example](#hello-make)   <-- Ctrl+clicking should jump to heading but it doesn't

## Hello `make`
```

- VSCode Version: Code 1.15.1 (41abd21afdf7424c89319ee7cb0445cc6f376959, 2017-08-16T18:05:38.342Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063

data.title: Customizable tabs in text editor: Multiple rows display, font size, grouping
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->
Feature request

Users always have bunch of tabs opened that do not fit the width of the text editor. They can scroll it with a mouse wheel, but it's not very observant.

It would be really great if vscode could display those **tabs on a multi row wrap panel** (like visual studio does). And provide some customizable settings like font size of tabs and ability to pin tabs (=create groups) and display it separately.

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.15.1
- OS Version: Windows

data.title: 'Reindent Lines' produces different indentation than 'Format Document' in TypeScript
Mac OS Sierra - Space/Desktop problem pumping/bomb OS load - Improve organization and productivity.
data.body:
similar issue https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=74812
iterm2 possible solution https://github.com/gnachman/iTerm2/blob/master/sources/iTermWindowImpl.m
This iterm solution is a tip from that chromium issue above
PS. I use Iterm and have nothing to complain about it.

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: latest
- OS Version: Mac OS 10.12.6

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open 3 projects. Separate it into 3 different spaces. Finalize the VS or restart the Mac. Using "window.restoreWindows": "all"
2. Reopen VS - all open right as before, but at the same space 0 (The current one).

The ideal would be re-open all three projects in the spaces as I determined. Thus improving productivity. And avoiding the stress of having to rearrange everything whenever you need to restart the MAC or even when there is a crash.

Best regards

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: doesn't matter for this.
